explanation: To determine whether OS_CountSemTake uses any compiler language extensions you must inspect the declarations/definitions that the function relies on, because extensions often appear in typedefs, macros or function prototypes. Rationale for each symbol: - int32: verify this typedef does not use non‑standard/extended integer keywords or attributes (e.g. __int128, __attribute__, __extension__, or compiler-specific typedefs). - osal_id_t: check the underlying type and any attributes or extensions used in its typedef. - OS_object_token_t: inspect the token type (struct/union/typedef) for bit‑fields, packed/aligned attributes, anonymous structs/unions or other extensions. - OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE: macros/enum values can be defined via extension constructs or complex macro expansions; inspect its definition for compiler‑specific constructs. - LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE: same as above — ensure the macro/enum expansion does not use extensions. - OS_SUCCESS: check this constant/macro for extension usage. - OS_ObjectIdGetById (declaration/definition): the prototype may include GCC/Clang attributes, non‑standard calling conventions, variadic extensions, or macros that expand to compiler extensions; inspect its declaration. - OS_CountSemTake_Impl (declaration/definition): inspect its prototype/definition for attributes or extension usage that would effectively make the call site use an extension. Inspecting these symbols (their typedefs, macros and function prototypes/definitions) is sufficient to decide whether the target function itself introduces or relies on any language extensions.
